The food was delivered pretty quickly and we got down to eating right away. I noticed that the curry had the right consistency and spice heat, the Katsu was a light golden brown w/o being over breaded or greasy, and the meat had almost no fat. Our plates also came w/a large side of rice and of course there were carrots and potatoes mixed in w/the curry sauce as is typical w/Japanese style curry plates.

Overall it was a great experience w/portions that were filling but didn't create stretch marks or cause food coma either. I'd definitely consider this my go to Japanese style curry house.
author: Gary T.

description:
More you come here, more addiction you get. It's a heavy food, so you can get two meals at once pretty much.

Life hack!
author: Silin N.

description: We were really happy with our experience here! We were planning on meeting some friends on Friday night, and they were running late. The friendly woman behind the counter took our orders and sat us at a table while we waited, and offered to hold our orders until our friends arrived, which we really appreciated (and did not expect). The food was great (pork katsu and chicken katsu curry) and the portion sizes were BIG. We'd definitely return- the food isn't perfect, but it's pretty darn good, and the service is equally great.
author: Charizard B.

description:
I believe something erupted, but I don't think it was Volcano. I had noticed it driving by on Geary a couple of times and giving it the "Hmmm...I should try that sometime". I have fond memories of my mom's chicken curry on brisk evenings in Dallas, Texas. Well, I convinced Jamie W. to take the stuffed-to-the-gills 38 line all the way to 20th Avenue from the Transbay Terminal. You definitely see clear evidence of the Darwinian theory pass through the bus during rush hour.

When we finally arrived, I was a bit disappointed to find that it's really more of a lunch counter in the guise of a restaurant. It has school cafeteria-style chairs and tables that look like the remnants of a spring clearance at IKEA, and even a refrigerated section where you pick up your own Diet Coke ($1.50) and Seaweed Salad ($2.50) which was crunchy fresh. I ordered the $6.50 Chicken Katsu Curry Noodles with Vegetables and asked for the hot and spicy treatment. I even added a split hard-boiled egg for a $1 more because well...I'm special.

The chicken was plentiful and the panko nice and crunchy. The noodles were OK, maybe a bit slippery, while the fresh vegetables were on the paltry side (just one new potato?). I have to say it was the curry sauce that was the most disappointing aspect. It was spicy enough but kinda watery. The description on the site asserts that it is "thickened with a roux" and slow cooked for 8-10 hours. Well, somebody must have been running a faucet into the pot because the sauce really had little texture to it. One thing I have to say is that the service by the young woman at the counter was excellent. She courteously came to check up on us.

FOOD - 3 stars...standard curry that's been kinda watered down
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...unmistakable air of a fast food joint...there was a picnic cooler for you to get ice
SERVICE - 4 stars...she was terrific
TOTAL - 3 stars...just barely...I need to bring my own cornstarch next time
author: Ed U.

description: The food here is very good and reasonably priced. I had the chicken katsu and it was the best I've ever had. This isn't some fancy type of place. It's good just for a couple friends and a nice homey meal. The staff isn't charming at all and the place looks like it could use more frequent cleaning, but these are the only critiques I have.
author: Alex B.

description:
Solid place for some yummy Japanese curry. You order at the counter and they'll bring your food to your seat. I ordered the Pork Katsu Curry (medium spicy!) and added the Spam Katsu and Potato Croquette. The curry arrived complete with potatoes and carrots, which was great because the carrots made me feel a little better about having a starchy and fried (and ultimately delicious) meal. 

The pork katsu itself was good - not too oily and perfectly crispy. The potatoes were a little bland - look, I get that it's just a potato, but I've had some fantastic potatoes in curry/stew before, and this wasn't it. (I would suggest letting the potatoes soak in the curry, but I understand that with the different spiciness of curries, this would probably be overdoing it for them.) HOWEVER, overall, the meal was great. I hadn't had spam katsu before, and it was really good. The potato croquette was also done nicely; it's just a pity I had over-ordered, as I couldn't finish it. 

Halfway through my meal, one of the staff asked me if I needed a box. I appreciate the sentiment and was glad she asked, but I could actually finish the whole thing (except for half of the croquette... I'm sorry, croquette!) - should I not have been able to? Nah, maybe I just had a huge appetite. I did run out of curry towards the end of my meal, which was a bummer as well as a surprise, since I'm notorious for never finishing gravies/sauces.

All in all, a good place. I'll probably be back if I'm looking for a curry fix!
author: Sarah B.

description: Went there for late lunch earlier today and just saw the food inspection safety alert on Yelp! Oooops! But to be fair it is tasty, cheap and chearful. The price is right ($10) for such a casual place, i ll go back again an hope this earning inspection is nothing to worry again! Well cooked meat in sauce there is not much risk!
author: Val M.

description:
I came to Volcano with my friend after visiting the newly opened Sharetea a few stores down. She told me she always wanted to try Volcano, and I was all up for trying something new, so we walked in, and ordered. At Volcano, you order at the counter first, and then take a seat. The lady behind the counter was incredibly friendly and kind, willing to help us and let us know what the most popular dishes were. According to her, the most popular dishes are the Chicken Katsu, and Pork Katsu. Now, I've have pork and chicken katsu before, but not curry style. I ordered the Pork Katsu and took a seat.

The food arrived at a pretty good pace, and I dug in. Now, I was incredibly hungry and could not wait to try it. When I saw the dish, I was disappointed. It just didn't look appetizing. The fried pork with the curry and rice with potatoes looked honestly unappealing. Anyhow, I gave it a shot. I put it in my mouth and was even more disappointed. The pork was chewy and flavorless. The curry was horrible, and the rice was too hearty. I thought it might have been just the first bite, so I took another. Nope. Nothing different. 

I was disappointed with Volcano because I paid for this lunch, which wasn't satisfying. I asked for a to-go box, thinking I might like it later, but I was wrong. When I went home, opened up the box, ready to microwave it, I was greeted with the most unpleasant smell of all time... IT SMELT LIKE VOMIT. Yes, vomit. Acidic, and sickening. I immediately threw it out into the trash. 

I really wanted to like you Volcano, I really did. Unfortunately I won't be coming back.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
Found this place by accident because I usually go next door for food. Went here on a Saturday and it wasn't that busy so I'm uncertain it would be during the weekdays. Plenty of seating but probably would be hard if you had a group of 8 or more. 

Two things I ordered

Mild Chicken Katsu Curry: Awesome! They give you plenty of chicken but I think they should of given more rice and curry to compensate the chicken
Croquette: Decent size but not big but flavorful. 

My other friends that with me ordered the hottest flavor which was Volcano. I'm not into spiciness that burn and makes your tongue bleed but man I tasted a tiny piece and it was surely spicy. 

I like the fact too that you can just get your own water and so that you wouldn't be dependent on a waiter. This place is more like a order then go sit down.
author: Nasser D.

description:
Japanese curry is something I HATE spending money on. It is ridiculously easy and cheap to make. Why buy overpriced curry when I can make it at home?

Because Volcano curry is awesome, that's why.

A Japanese curry that is actually SPICY. That makes me so happy. And the flavors rock. And the food is delicious. And everything about the entire experience just... ITS DELICIOUS SO GO EAT IT OKAY?!

It really warms you up, and God knows you need warming up with you're in the foggiest, coldest part of San Francisco!
author: Jade R.

description:
Yes. 
Curry is delicious. Soup is too.
Get the pickled stuff.
The service is very friendly as well.
author: Gingersnappy T.

description:
I visited Volcano on a Tuesday evening around 7:30 p.m. When my boyfriend and I walked in, there was only one other customer there. We walked right up to the counter and ordered:

-Chicken curry: mild. The chicken was very moist. 
-Katsu curry: mild. The Katsu was nicely prepared. It was very crispy on the outside, and the meat was very moist on the inside. 

Both plates came with a generous portion of rice, a lot of curry sauce, meat, carrots and potatoes.  The curry was really delicious and very comfort food-y. 

The feeling of the restaurant is very casual. You order at the counter, get your own utensils and water, choose a table, and put away your own dishes. The restaurant was clean and the workers were friendly.  As my boyfriend and I were finishing up our meals, a huge rush of customers came in. It seems like a lot of customers are neighborhood residents and get their food to-go.  

Overall, the food is pretty good and it comes out hot and in a timely manner.  I don't really know how or want to cook curry at home, so this place is great for whenever I want some curry. 

Notes:
-Parking in the area may be difficult depending on the time.
-Use Scoutmob for 50% off!
-In addition to curry plates, they also offer noodles and sandwiches.
author: Samantha L.

description: A bit pricey for what it is... Japanese/Hawaiian. Flavors weren't that impressive either.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
I love spicy food!

Japanese curry with customized add-on options and different spicy levels! How much better does it get? Order a curry rice plate, choose the meat you want, and add a whole bunch of shebang in there! Boom - you got your yummy, spicy and filling dinner!

I usually get Tonkatsu curry rice plate... Tried fried shrimp once but I'm not a big fan of tempera style fried shrimp so I went back to tonkatsu. The curry comes with a variety of vegetables such as zucchini, potatoes, carrots, etc. Tonkatsu is tender, panko crusted and very juicy. 

I like to add:
Calamari 
Fried oysters
Boiled egg
Fukujinzuke pickles (Not all of them in my curry at the same time, I rotate them depending on my cravings)

Level of spiciness: 
VOLCANO - always!

Boom! Affordable and quick curry fix!
ITADAKIMASU!
author: Mindy C.

description:
The one thing I have to gripe about is how they charge you for every add on.
I mean $1.25 for ONE potato croquette? Granted it is a delicious, crispy on the outside, soft in the inside little fried patty, but damn. Can't forget to ask for extra fukujinzuke pickles, oh wait that'll cost you another $1.25.

Considering that the most basic curry will put you at $7, any add on will continue to rack up for a $10+ plate of curry.
However, it is a great bowl of Japanese curry that'll hit the spot, especially if you have a craving. It's Geary though, so parking is going to be a hassle.
author: Jenna H.

description: Their curry is REALLY good! I recommend the chicken katsu curry and or pork katsu with a potato croquette. Went here a couple of times with family and its always really tasty. For spice, medium is a safe bet but hot seems to be more flavirful. The fried fish however wasnt to my liking, but i love how this place allows you to choose what you want how spicy and you can add toppings too! They sell sandwiches too! The pricing is decent and the service is good. It is self clean but you dont have to tip at least. Lol. Def. Coming back again.
author: Lena T.

description:
Solid, solid curry house in San Francisco. Definitely my go-to place for curry. 

Honestly, it's really hard to go wrong with anything from here. Their curry recipe has been passed down in the family (or so I've heard), and it has a pretty unique flavor to it - a nice balance of tanginess and spiciness.

Their Chicken Katsu Curry is definitely the bomb! Another thing is their Spam Katsu Sandwich is pretty satisfying as well (it's served on a Hawaiian dinner roll). A lot of things people don't try that are really good as well are their Curry Noodle Soups - for those of you who are more of a noodle person rather than a rice person. 

Overall, good food, pretty good service, and a nice price.
author: Calvin H.

description:
To start off I want to say I LOVED the food, this restaurant is not getting 1 star because of its food. I am giving Volcano 1 start because the charged a tip on my credit card that I did not authorize, even after I left them a cash tip. 

So the story behind it, was looking for a place to eat, the Cajun place down the street me and my friend wanted to go to was closed. We saw this place and a burrito place and decided this place looked more adventurous and unique so we figured we would try it out. 

We got suggestions from the lady working there, I got the oyster curry, which was amazing. I paid with a card and left $2 dollars in tip at the counter where we ordered. Ate the food, went home. I checked my card the next day and it said there was and extra $2 charged to it for tip that I had not written on the receipt.  

Not only is this bad form and service but it is ILLEGAL! regardless of how small it is, that is stealing and not what I would expect from a place like this. Bad move Volcano!
author: Taylor S.

description: Love this place. The curry itself is decent since it's flavorful but not exploding with flavor. But, the tonkatsu with all the options for add-ons make it really worth it. The rice is good, too. For 9 bucks, you will feel full and if you like, the double volcano curry will melt you.
author: Ruobin W.

description: I like this place for a fast Curry fix if you don't feel like driving all the way to Japantown. It is not the world's best curry, but I have never had a meal there I did not like. One of the main reasons I go is for the very cute girls they have working the counter. Always makes a trip there a joy. Although, I do not see the cute Blonde Asian girl there as much anymore. I say give this place a try :)
author: Jerry A.

description:
Wow, I just thoroughly enjoyed a slice of Japan that I've not tasted in some time, pork katsu curry.

Volcano offers 4 levels of heat when it comes to their curry sauce. Muggins here ordered hot and I cannot even contemplate ordering Volcano.

Would my teeth, all head hair fall out were I to cross over to the dark side where Volcano sauce awaits? I'll admit fear at the thought but will give it a go when next I visit and I will visit again and again and again.
author: Jay D.

description: The best got dang spicy cuisine West of the Divisdaero.  Cheap, delicious, filling and it burns so good.
author: Chris S.

description:
Recently came back, the service was actually good,
She were pretty nice.
I enjoy coming back here.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
3.4 star!
Very Basic Japanese Curry that I did not know it is Japo-style curry when I was kid eating this kind of curry in Japan.
The curry is decent flavor for a "Japo-style" version.
The 7 bucks chicken katsu and pork katsu are pretty good.
The steamed rice is decent.
Satisfying but, you won't get a feeling like "I'm hooked" or "I'm addicted".
After finish having the curry, I walked out, I totally forgot the flavor of the curry I just had. That never happened to me. Every time when I had a curry, I do remember the flavor.

The place is clean and good service but the reason why the curry is not WOW, like that Soup-Nazi because i think the cook.
It seems like the cook only follows instruction manual exactly. 
Zero imagination for create something better, something really good.

Curry, to me, border line to poison kind of food.
Physically and mentally dependent on and unable to stop taking about it without incurring adverse effects.
Kimuchi is anther one. So as Natto.
So that Curry should be a dangerously hot food.
Kill me softly? Hell No!
Kill me dangerously Hard!.
That should be it.

The place can not be Curry Nazi.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Maybe 2.5 stars at best!  I guess I don't listen too well because with all of the bad reviews so far I still mustered up enough curiosity to go inside and give it a try.  The curry is not earth-moving as a volcano should be and quite weak in flavor, but if I'm ever in the area and really desperate for food I'd go back.

The place was surprisingly busy on a Sunday afternoon with every table occupied inside.  You can smell the curry when you walk into the restaurant, and it smelled pretty good.  After standing at the counter for quite some time indecisive about what I wanted to eat I finally ordered the chicken curry with a potato croquette added on for an extra dollar.  I didn't see the brown rice or noodle option (another dollar) until I had already placed my order.  They give you a number and you can go find a place to sit and wait.

It was about an eight minute wait when my number was called.  This is what it looked like (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WnQoN1uV65vacUj0q1TgoQ?select=u-crixsd7MYpKq4tiQKoyw).  I picked up a piece of potato and bit into it.  The curry was very mild and hardly present, and there was a lot more sauce than there was rice.  Someone must stand in the kitchen and count vegetables because there were exactly two pieces of potatoes, two pieces of carrot and two slices of zucchini.  The chicken was moist and both skinless and boneless.  I agree with other reviewers that the vegetables must be pre-cooked and then reheated.  If you notice in the photo it looks like the sauce was just ladled over the potatoes because not all of the veggies were covered in sauce.  My guess would be the microwave because the vegetable pieces cooled very quickly and were cold to the bite within minutes.

The potato croquette, while on the small side for a buck, was actually very good.  The pickled vegetables served on top of the rice were crunchy but lacked a good vinegar and pickle flavor.  The paper plate and plastic utensils don't bother me as much as it does other reviewers.  When you've had as many Hawaiian lunch plates and Chinese take out as I've had you kind of get used to food served in/on disposable products.  The staff was very friendly.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Fair price for a belly-bursting, like a volcano, curry experience! Now that I live even closer, I can count on using that rewards point system to keep me coming back, especially to claim the free curry meal! muaha.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I actually been here once 2 years ago. It was late at night and frankly I just don't remember it.

Seeing how it is reasonably price I took my friend here for lunch. I ordered the beef curry while he ordered the chicken curry. It is reminiscent of a fast food joint. You order, pay, and grab a seat. The lady will then bring you the food. 

There were plastic cups with straws and utensils that you grab yourself. You get a good helping of food. Half rice and half curry with meat and veggies. The veggies were carrots, potatoes, and zucchini. All very tender and went well with the curry. The beef didn't look too appetizing but it was actually very soft and tender. You can tell its been cooking for a while in the curry. 

Probably not the best curry I have ever had and it could have been better BUT it was good for the price. I was pleasantly full and wouldn't mind coming back here. 

The girl came over and took away our empty plates even though we were suppose do it ourselves.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This is my go-to restaurant when I am craving 'not so heavy' curry and rice. They offer japanese type curry with either beef, chicken katsu, or pork katsu. Forewarning, if you are expecting Tani's kitchen quality, it is comparable but I still like Tani's better but its farther away(Westlake) and has few seats so you may need to wait a while. 

I typically order the chicken katsu with brown rice and add extra toppings of sausage, zucchini and calamari. If you are not in the mood for being healthy, I definitely recommend white rice over brown rice, especially with the curry.

Parking can be a pain in this area so you might be driving around for a while but what I usually do is order online and double park quickly to pick up the food.

Food Highlight: Chicken katsu with white rice and order online to expedite your food if you are picking it up
author: Rich L.

description: Great katsu and overall great asian food. You get a full meal for $10! Good service and vibes, artwork is cool too.
author: Gavin H.

description: Nice place, get there all the time. Try noodles instead of rice, will be totally different experience.
author: Louie Z.

description:
Back when I lived in Hokkaido, Japan I would eat soup curry for dinner every Sunday. Its spicy and comforting flavor helped usher the coming work week with confidence.

A few years ago I moved to the Richmond District and was excited to see a Japanese curry restaurant and I quickly too up my Sunday curry tradition.

I always order the chicken katsu curry, hot and play around with the toppings. I'm always sad when it's done. The chicken is good, the panko breading crisp, the curry delicious.

The service staff is also friendly, charming, and helpful.
author: D. M.

description:
This is a new restaurant that serves Japanese-style curry. The name "Volcano" might infer a hot version of curry, but Japanese curry is tame, when compared to Thai curries or others for example.

Currently in SF, you can get a homestyle curry version (Muracci's - the best by far), or the generic Japanese brown curry made from instant powder (what most other places serve), like this place. Overall, the food is okay, although there's room for improvement. Unremarkable is more accurate, but I don't want to be too harsh since it just opened. I wish that the vegetables were cooked with the curry, and not cooked separately and added during assembly. It's a value priced place - emphasis on price (under $10 including drink) over quality, so within that category it's 3 stars.

*****************************

Updated rating: 3.5 stars.

Food quality has improved a lot many months after it first opened. Although the curry gravy is still not as good as Muracci's. Even the popular Curry House chain is better than this version.

Regarding the improvements: the quality of the fried food items is now excellent (pork/chicken katsu, croquette). And they've expanded the menu with a few appetizers, like a side order of fried calamari (6 rings) for $1.50, non-curry rice plates, noodle soups and sandwiches. All items remain affordable for under $8, plus a frequent diner card gets u a free topping on every 3rd visit.
author: Luis C.

description:
OMG this place always hits the spot on a cold ass day!  
Since its been a while since i came here,ca i forgot what i ordered last time (well now i remember since i just checked my yelp review) but i guess i ordered the same thing and man...it is spicy!

I guess they got a new girl but she's super nice, she brought over our orders and came back to check to see if everything is alright (this is not one of those places i expect her to ask but thanks!) 

she even told me that theres a secret spice level call double volcano...OMG =D!! i'll try next time...oh how my mouth drools for your delicious thick curry!

I'm sure they dont have to but again, self served water with ICE! and they even provided katsu sauce and siracha (none for me...shocking...i know)
author: Laurie W.

description: I stopped here one day to try the Katsu curry. The Japanese curry here is one of the best in the city. I was not disappointed. They delivered a hot meal that was fresh and flavorful. I wish they would put a little more curry over the rice though. The dining area could use a little more attention, but otherwise it is a good place to visit on a cold day.
author: Charles B.

description: They have levels higher than Volcano!  I got x10 and it is amazing.  I'd say 6/10 with 3/10 being Tabasco level heat.  And the flavor shines through.  Love the pork katsu and croquettes with that delicious sauce.
author: Audrey D.

description:
So glad I can get amazing curry without schlepping to japantown. I had volcano spicy Kara Age curry and am officially hooked. I want to try them all! 
Super friendly staff, looked good for take out too.
author: Adrianna M.

description:
OH GOD, YES PLEASE! How have I not reviewed this place sooner?

Do yourself a favor and try brown rice, extra pickles and chicken karaage (carrots only). I ate here 2 weeks straight once to see if I would get sick of it. Nope nope nope. 

Even if I don't live in the area anymore, I would take a side-trip to come here any day!
author: Charles P.

description:
There's nothing fancy or gourmet about Volcano, but you walk away totally satisfied. The pork katsu is one of the juiciest I've had. This is down and dirty Japanese curry, so it has less curry flavor than the Indian variety and a sweet finish. As you might imagine, Volcano puts some heat in theirs. I got the hot version and I was sweating for an hour. The Volcano version is probably deadly.

The woman who works at the register is a force of nature. Not only does she take your order, she cleans the tables and brings your order out with a smile. 

I ordered the katsu coupled with the sausage. Which sounds like pork overkill, maybe even weird. But, man, did it hit the spot. And to think I almost missed it on the menu.

My only complaint would be that the steamed rice made the bottom of the katsu soggy. But that's me being fussy and Volcano is decidedly not.
author: William B.

description:
The spam katsu mini sandwich is delicious! I'm sad I didn't order more of those! 

I'm not a big fan of curry, but I decided to try this place out anyway. I ordered the Chicken katsu curry plate that comes with white rice, and I got two mini spam katsu sandwiches.
Chicken katsu was good and dipped in the curry it was better. The curry was ok, I liked that it was spicy (you get to choose the level of spiciness you want), but like I said I don't like most curry. The curry would have been better if it had more than just potato and carrot in it, or at least more pieces of what it did have. Also the potato wasn't cooked all the way through and some pieces were kinda crunchy. 

I think I would go back but stick to the sandwiches!
author: Alejandra I.

description: This is my favorite place to get Japanese curry in the city. The Volcano spiciness level is just right and they give you very generous portions. I really love the tonkatsu curry rice place. I'm not particularly fond of the carrots and potatoes. I believe they may cook them separately, so they don't absorb the delicious curry flavor. I'm happy that they use FiveStar. You get a free curry dish after 10 purchases. :)
author: Anna S.

description:
This is my 4th times being here.
i like the spicy spicy japanese curry Katsu and this is pretty authentic.
I will keep going  back again.
author: Mikey N.

description:
Soo good! Eat here once and you'll be craving it- good thing it's just around the corner. I love the crispy katsu: veggie and pork are my go to dishes. 

The onion ginger pork curry they often have on special is awesome. One of my favorite things. The noodle soups are great too. Pretty large portions and great prices, under $10 per meal.

I always get hot spicy and it's just right... Haven't yet been daring enough to try the volcano spicy.

You can customize your plate with a whole range of toppings, everything from boiled egg, shredded cheese, and zucchini, to mini sausages, and spinach.

If you eat in, service is usually very attentive and friendly. To go orders come up quick.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Great price, great food. What more can you ask for? 

If you are looking for a great place with fabulous flavors, then you must try the curry.  I love spicy food but the volcano level is burning hot, so after a few attempts, I had to drop to hot level.  The volcano level will make your eyes water, nose run, and sweat dripping from your head...but it is so good!

They offer a loyalty card program where you gather stamps to get free topping and eventually a free meal.
author: Panda G.

description: Delicious. Had the chicken katsu with hot level sauce. It was great and so was the service.
author: Robert G.

description:
After a failed attempt of attending the overly crowded Ramen festival, my friends and I had our eyes (and stomachs) set on something Japanese. At least this way, we can redeem ourselves. 

Upon entering, the restaurant was full of people. There were two lines, one to order and one to wait for a table. Yeah, that busy. 

Looking at the menu, the Beef Burger Steak caught my eye. So I ordered a curry plate of the steak, along with toppings (boiled egg, potato croquette). My total came to ~$11.00. Ok, not so bad.

The wait for our food took around 25-30 minutes. Finally the food arrives. First thing i notice, there is a LOT of food on this plate. Luckily my hunger peaked at this point, so it was time to go apeshit on this food. 

Cut a piece of my Beef Burger Steak, dipped it in my curry sauce and took a bite outa that sucker. First thoughts? Good. With the hard boiled egg? Even better. Overall the plate was splendid. I didn't really care for the potato corquette, as there were already potatoes that came with the plate (along with carrots, so the potato corquette didn't taste any better at that point). 

Do I recommend this place? Sure, the quality of food is good and worth and is set at a decent price. The wait kind of sucked but I'm guessing I came in at a bad time, hence the long wait. Will be coming back to try out their other plates.
author: Jonathan L.

description: One of my favorite places for curry. My favorite is chicken katsu curry. I also love how there are different levels of spicyness you can get here, because I can't handle spicy at all!
author: Samantha Y.

description: I'm from Hawaii & this place reminds me of Curry House. Very comparable actually. I got the chicken katsu curry with cheese, side potato croquette. The portions are huge & good for atleast 2 meals. Would definitely go back!
author: Alysha K.

description:
One of the hidden places in San Francisco where you can get a ton of food for an affordable price. 

I got the chicken teriyaki, and it came with a salad, rice and soup. It was around $10 for all of this. I didn't take any home because I was very hungry, but I totally should have taken it home because it was way too much for my stomach. I didn't vomit, though, so, like, that's a testament to how good the food was. My stomach locked it in.

The ambiance sucks. It's small and reminds me of a poor middle school's cafeteria. Also, I was in a large party and we had to sit apart from each other. It gets packed pretty quickly (which is another testament to how good the food is) but the chairs are super uncomfortable. Maybe get this to go. Yeah, definitely get it to go, because then you're already home and can easily save some, rather than asking for a box, which can be intrusive sometimes.

If this was a drive thru, it'd be 5 stars. That also sounds as bad as "The food was so good, I didn't vomit," but trust me, it's a good thing.
author: Sam D.

description:
Tomato chicken is a fantastic choice every time I go here. It taste nice and clean, the curry had a chance to develop a nice clean and tasty profile and feels great on the pallet of your tongue.

Brown rice is always a nice option but it cost some extra (not sure what it is but it can not be much because the whole lunch dish is around $11). 

Ask for extra pickles if you like that crunchy sweet flavor. 
The service is always nice and fast. The entry takes just a few minutes to be delivered to the table. Overall is a great neighborhood place with tasty Japanese inspired food.
The only minus is the absence of the ramen option on their menu. Serving Udon is great but why not ramen? After dropping a number of notes in their suggestion box and having several conversations with employees to no avail I gave up on that idea and now instead I go to NoKnan just couple of blocks between 15th and 16th where they serve great ramen dishes.

Overall Volcano is a great, and can be healthy after workout hand out spot on Geary between 18th and 19th Ave.
author: Xela H.

description: I'm a fan! Small modest place with staff who are friendly and attentive. The chicken katsu curry is great! Crispy, tender, with a medium-spicy creamy curry.. Mm mm! It's a fantastic deal that will surely fill and warm you up for under $8. We also got the spam sandwich, I mean really, who can pass that up? I'll definitely be coming back here.
author: Andrew T.

description: If they only had beer it would be 5 stars. Also their menu is a bit peace meal. The parking availability and casualness however are what make it my destination.
author: Stanley J.

description: Awesome place for a quick bite. I love their curry and it's very similar to curry I've had in Japan. Great topping options and friendly staff. If you can handle spice, Volcano is delicious. If not, BEWARE!
author: Justin S.

description:
I love Japanese curry and I love this place. I love that you can put whatever you want on it as well. It's not expensive either. The girl(s) working there is very nice too. 

"I'll take a potato croquette with fried shrimp curry, please."... Yum.

I find some of the lower rated reviews weird and I even wonder if they went to the same place cause this curry is solid and I've been to Japan and ate curry. Have they?!?! :D
author: Giordano G.

description: Local fav or ours.  Sweaty brow level hot curry if you want it.  Solid and consistent.  We're regulars.
author: Patrick M.

description: Amazing price and curry!! The best that I ever had! It can be super duper Spicy!! If you can handle it, order the volcano one...you will explode like a volcano haha!!
author: Elsa Mandy G.

description:
Yaaaay! I finally got to come here for the first time since I bookmarked this place on Yelp!

I`ll be honest, curry isn`t one of my favorite foods on a Japanese menu, but a whole restaurant dedicated to it? Why not! It`s traditional, it`s hot, it`s fresh, it`s delicious!

My only complaint about the food is that the meat & toppings are pretty pricey... but also I can`t REALLY complain about it because they give a good amount of food that you ordered. When I first entered the restaurant I stared down the menu for a good 10 minutes trying to decide what to put on my curry and kept I contemplating if I should order more or less on my plate. I ended up getting the medium beef curry with croquette on the side and my oh my... did it send me to heaven and back. The curry is excellent, there is nothing else to say about it but it`s as authentic as it can get. The beef..... meh it was dry, good thing about the curry because it did make it taste better, but biting into the meat was like biting into liver... ew liver. Everything else was just good, great, AMAZING! I can`t wait to visit this spot again!
author: Johanah I.

description: Okay, so I love this place as well as Muracci's, but I'm giving it 4 stars because it's in a more accessible location away from the hustle and bustle of downtown.  Plus, it's sooooo spicy and sooo good!!!!!   I was hungover, so the burn was bad, but I couldn't stop eating it!!  They charge for almost everything, but it's cheap and the food is good!
author: Jae W.

description:
My sister absolutely loves this place, and I can see why. I ordered over the phone, and my two orders were ready within 10 minutes.  I had the chicken katsu (I believe it was about $8). The togo box had rice and the chicken katsu. The curry was in a separate container which was great--no spillage. The curry was nice and hot. The katsu was super crispy and delicious. The meal as a whole was really great, but it didn't live up to the hype (for me at least). Nevertheless, Volcano is a great spot to get some awesome curry. 
Bottom line: would recommend!!!!
author: K T.

description:
This is my favorite place in SF to get Japanese curry. I love my curry extra spicy and Volcano Curry is the best place to get that. I spent some time living in Japan and would always get concerned looks when I would order my curry "karai" (spicy).  The hottest "volcano" level spicy curry here is at least as hot or hotter than anything I had in Japan. It will likely get your nose running, but if you love delicious, extra spicy Japanese curry make sure to try Volcano Curry! You can of course order your curry mild, but what's the fun in that.

I recommend the chicken or pork katsu and add a [hard] boiled egg. The curry noodle soups are great too!

I've eaten here at least 10 times and the service had always been fast and friendly.

Seating is somewhat limited, but the place is not usually overly crowded. You can order To Go and they package everything in nice separate containers so it doesn't get messy on the way home.
author: Rob L.

description:
My favorite curry spot in Richmond! Don't forget to pick up a point card. 10 stamps gets you a free curry, but every 4 gets you a free topping!

The toppings are of a decent size considering they're usually $1-2. The veggie curry is loaded with delicious zucchini, which I'd previously not seen in Japanese curry.

Please, TIP the cashier if you're eating in. You order at the register, but the cashier doubles as a waiter(ess).
author: Sterling D.

description:
A very interesting place to eat. Wouldn't had gone if I really wasn't hungry for curry. The flavors aren't bad, but just so simple that one could get the Japanese curry out of a box and add a couple potatoes and pour it over rice to save a few dollars.

I would surely avoid paying for the toppings. Just save your money or use it to get their mini sandwiches.
author: M C.

description:
I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry and added two sausages on the side, it was alright. I wish there was just a little more taste to it because I got mild and I still couldn't taste anything. But i'm probably gonna come back and try a different plate this time!

One thing that I didn't like about the place was how there were dead flies on the side counters. It just really bothered me and made me question if they notice these dead flies...
author: Angela L.

description: I've loved coming here! When I came here tonight to pick up my order, there were many people in line that I have ever seen for a long time. While I was waiting I like the cashier didn't look to happy because she have to do two things at once like serving and taking people's order.  I got the beef curry which was the BOMB.COM , but I would love to come here again.
author: Brittany L.

description: Happy I found this place! Not as good as Curry House in Cupertino, but the variety of toppings is diverse and delicious
author: Danny L.

description: I came here with family and friends, 8 of us. The service was quick and friendly. Everything we ordered was delicious! The only thing was that some of the potatoes in my hub's curry were under cooked. My son is only 8 and he ordered the teriyaki chicken plate, it came with a ton of rice, teriyaki chicken, salad and some miso soup. I was so surprised that he finished most of it.. more than half! he's a picky eater and most of the time he struggles at mealtime but, not this time. My daughter got the tomato chicken curry. She loved it and almost finished it, only a couple bites left. Oh, the place is kind of small but, I was still able to fit my stroller in there.
author: Diana T.

description: I liked it but did not feel the love.
author: Morris R.

description:
Volcano is my favorite go-to lunch spot in the Richmond!  The menu is simple, the service is fast, and the food is satisfying.

I don't love spicy food, so I always order mild.  My friend, who loves extreme spiciness, ordered double volcano.  She loved it, but admitted it burned.
author: Barbara E.

description:
My go to place for Japanese curry in the city. If you've had Curry House Coco Ichibanya and hoping this place would compare, don't bother... nothing is as good as Curry House. Regardless this place is still good. Plus it's in my neighborhood!  

Pros:
1) different toppings options
2) spicy level options
3) brown rice option
author: Wei-Wei C.

description: OMG their curry is so good! specifically their chicken katsu curry. i came here today for my first time and loooved the katsu curry. the katsu is crispy and their curry is amazing! my boyfriend who also isn't a curry lover has officially been converted lol. can't wait to come back and try other menu items!
author: Kim S.

description: The best cheap katsu there is. Used to live around the corner and went at least once a week. Live further away now, but still try to swing by. Great staff, good sides, fast service. Wonderful.
author: Wil T.

description:
I am a big fan of curry! I have been eating curry ever since I was a kid.
I like this place because you can choose how spicy you want it.
One plate is just right, will fill you up. :)
author: Teresa C.

description: Curry Katsu was excellent!  You can  pick the spiciness of your curries from mild, hot, volcano. Volcano is too spicy for me, hot was just right. Fair prices, and service was great.
author: Mav M.

description:
My friend come here every time he go home to SF. I made my brother drove me here across time just to try it. Parking sucks around richmond and the place was smaller than i expected. The curry imo was over priced. They have some small portion of rice, with f load of curry sauce and slab of w/e meat you order. and inside the curry there was 1 small piece of carrot and potato. 

The curry was way more than the amount of rice so i was pretty much drinking curry for part of the meal. It definitely taste decent but for ~8 bucks i would rather eat else where.
author: Frederick A.

description:
I completely forgot I had a Scoutmob 50% off deal here until I read someone else's review earlier. I had dinner here a few hours ago with my mom. Hardly ever do I give 5 star reviews but Japanese curry is just that good. Although Volcano does not top Muracci's in the FiDi, it's quite up there on my list of yummy eats. The price is alright even without 50% off but the toppings will really add to your bill if you want those.

It's good that the menu is not too extensive as the queue picks up very quickly. There are about 10 tables in the restaurant so it was quite tricky to find a space to sit. Good thing there was an open table and I grabbed it before a line formed behind me.

Since the maximum discount is $10, I tried to reach $20 worth of food to get as much flavor on my dish as possible. I got the staple pork katsu curry with #3 hot sauce ($7.25), tofu nuggets, eggplants, zucchinis, and sausages. My mom didn't know what to order so I just ordered the chicken katsu curry with #2 medium sauce and no toppings ($6.95). The total was $21.37 but the Scoutmob brought it down to $13! Strangely enough, there was a phone-in order and the credit card machine doesn't work when the phone is in use. The line got really long since the order took a while. 

All the utensils, ice, and water are self-serve so get what you need. You also have to bus your own table and when we moved tables to a larger one, the lady before us clearly did not dump her cup. Whore. 

The place was packed and our orders took about 10 minutes to come to the table. It's nice that customers aren't called out to pick up plates. It adds a touch of customer service which is excellent. With so many toppings, my plate was full to the brim with sauce and vegetables. My mom's plate was just the basic serving with carrots, potatoes, and zucchinis. 

The hot curry sauce wasn't really spicy which is alright but I really like to fire up my senses. Next time I will get the #4 volcano curry sauce. My mom's sauce didn't taste spicy at all but she felt it was too spicy for her. Oh well, we all have our own opinions. I'm very satisfied that the amount of curry sauce was enough for all the rice to have flavor. I hate when restaurants hold back on the highlight of their menu. There is a small distinction between chicken and pork katsu but pork is definitely the better. The eggplants (+$1.50) and tofu nuggets (+$1.25) were the best toppings and I highly recommend getting those! 

I was full from finishing the whole plate and ate half of my mom's dish too. The cashier checked on the customers when she was making rounds cleaning and such which adds another personal touch in customer service. I didn't know Volcano Curry was such a popular destination for richmond district residents. Around 8pm when we finished, people were waiting for tables, sadly. I can't wait to come back and try the curry noodles to see if it stacks up against Muracci's ramen.
author: Dominic T.

description:
To start: I have a peanut allergy. Japanese curry is on my list of foods that are generally "safe" for me to eat. 

I ate here a couple of years ago with no problems, but I guess sometime between then and yesterday the curry recipe began including peanuts. No allergy warning or ingredients list to let you know.

 I would say I should have known better, should have asked, but I've had lots of Japanese curry and never with peanuts in it. Please put a warning somewhere in the shop or on your website. A small sign would be totally sufficient.

Otherwise, if you don't have allergies, totally go here. The curry is good and the staff is nice, albeit wholly unprepared for an allergic reaction.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Ordered the chicken katsu curry, "volcano" hot.  I'd be lying if I said that I wasn't slightly worried I'd become a fire-breathing dragon out of one end and/or the other, but if you can handle Sriracha, the volcano level of spiciness is child's play.

I love that they offer brown rice, but I hate that I forgot to ask for it.  Oh well.  Next time.  I'll get you!  *shakes fist*  Seriously, I'll get you [brown rice].  There's really no way of mitigating the unhealthiness of such a meal (well, there are but that's beside the point), but I was still kinda sad that out of the three of us, I got the least amount of carrots.

A final note, I wish they gave more curry.  If I'm already wasting calories on empty carbs, they better not be naked.

UPDATE:  The tomato chicken curry was SO good.  I don't think I'd order anything else.  And right before we left, seeing that neither of us had shed a tear or returned for more water, the cashier informed us there is a level of spiciness beyond "volcano" that is not listed on the menu.  Next time, donezo.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Really love this place! A cheap, easy go to when you want some spicy got curry. I go here all the time when I was good Katsu and curry that's cheap!

I wish they combined their stamp cards bc I always forget mine at home...
author: Cindy C.

description:
For fast lunches down in the FiDi I used to go to this crappy, grease covered Chinese restaurant and get chicken curry loaded with potatoes and carrots for $5. Yum! That place got axed and it's now a Perilla, but fond memories of cheap, delicious, and (probably unsanitary) daily curry remain. 

Since then, several Japanese & Thai curries have tried to fill that void in my stomach with little success. Enter Volcano. Not a gourmet experience by any means, but the flavors and style fill that yummy, yummy need for curry! Their chicken also comes thick and delicious with potatoes and (not nearly enough) carrots. 

The place is also clean...which justifies the $3 price hike over the long gone standby...and the service is friendly. The walls are covered in come cute art-vertisements. I'm spending a little more time out in the Richmond lately, and I'm really glad Volcano is here to feed me with some rustic, spicy goodness.
author: Luke M.

description:
TL;DR: Don't have your hopes up for THE BEST customer service. Great food but when its busy... they can be really REALLY rude.

So first off, I lived around here for many years and I've been here MANY TIMES since they first started up and gaining popularity. They are really affordable, really delicious, really clean*, superb service*, and a great place to hang out with friends/hold school fundraisers.
(*see below)

You might be wondering why it's a 3 star review then... Well today (7/19/2014) was by far the WORST experience I've ever had at a restaurant, in general. I've never felt so insulted and disgusted by the customer service my friends and I received today. First off, it wasn't SUPER busy... just the usual busy Volcano Curry where they have a influx of customers as people were leaving. 
The tables weren't wiped down after people left and the floors... oh the floors... were disgusting. There were pieces of food all over the floor and curry too.
That wasn't even the worst part.
After being tired from a long day, me and my friends were exhausted and so happy to see a free table open in our favorite neighborhood curry place. We sat down, placed our stuff down, and got in line to order. I was just sitting down watching our stuff since my boyfriend was just going to order my food when the waitress comes over, points to a group of three that just walked through the door, and tells me, 
"Excuse me, are you going to be ordering?"  
Me: "Oh yeah, my friends are all in line."
"Well, they ordered before you so can I ask you to move so they can have a spot to sit down?"
At this point, I was starting to get annoyed. She asks me, a customer, to move because a previous customer of hers LEFT AND DIDNT SAVE THE SEATS.... 
I grabbed my friends stuff and mines, and went to stand with my friends who were RIGHT IN FRONT OF THE CASHIER. Then she asks us... as we're just standing around not knowing what to do... since we just lost the only free table... "Are you guys going to order?" We said no because we didn't really have a table and then she suggested to either wait for a table or "You can get take-out." 
Whew... thats only the first of it. We decided to wait for a table and just order a little after she asked us to order. (Cause this place's curry is BOMB) 
We get our table and our food starts to come... then some alcohol-smelling homeless person stumbles in and starts harassing my friend. For a good 5 minutes, he's chatting up my friends (a girl and a guy) and bugging them and allowing them to eat. I stood up and went to the waitress and asked her, "Excuse me, theres this hobo harassing my friend over there, can you ask him to leave?" She stares at him runs to the kitchen to talk to the chef (which I'm guessing is the owner) and comes back. 
I see the owner(?) come out the kitchen for a bit then looks at the homeless man from afar. He then heads back into the kitchen... stares at him from there and continues working. 
I was furious. I asked them politely and I'm pretty sure they know that they had the power to kick someone out of their property. 
Fed up with the terrible service I was getting, I stood up, went up to the homeless man, my boyfriend stood up, and we told him to stop harassing my friends.
He left after a minute or two and then I proceeded to enjoy my curry. At this point I was cursing pretty loudly... I'm pretty sure everyone in the restaurant saw how I had to handle the situation myself since the waitress nor the chef was going to help me.
As I was eating.... my friend told me another TERRIBLE thing this waitress had done. His total was 11.09 and he wanted to pull out a quarter from his pocket since he didn't want  91 cents in change. He asked her "Hold on, can I get a quarter since I don't want 91 cents in change?" She then replies, 'Ain't nobody got time for that." and proceeds to give him 91 cents in change. RUDE! It takes less time to get 16 cents than 91 cents!

As we were leaving, the same waitress was cleaning out the dirty dishes bin and she asks us."So... did he just end up leaving?" Pissed off, my boyfriend replied angrily, "No, we had to bug him to leave." She had the NERVE to ask us.

All in all, the food is really good here... but MAN some of the waitresses here are TERRIBLE TERRIBLE people.
author: Carina C.

description: This place is not as great as it used to be. Service was pretty bad. When I arrived, no one was there to take my order. It was not until one of the kitchen staff told the cashier, who was kneeling behind the counter (I couldn't see here), probably on her phone, that there was someone at the counter. She had a stone cold face when taking my order, no smiling, and was even mumbling, so I couldn't really hear what she was saying. Food was just okay. I got pork katsu curry with an egg. The potatoes seemed still a little raw to me. They were skimpy on the red pickled radish; I only got 3 small pieces, where as other photos I see on Yelp has at least eight to ten. Won't be coming back.
author: Genie Y.

description: Yummmmm I usually order the chicken katsu curry or vegetable curry noodle soup with a side of fukujinzuke pickles!
author: Jane Y.

description:
Very good Katsu Curry, better than Muraccis Japanese Curry & Grill :)
If only they deliver! :P
author: Lyn X.

description: Great neighborhood spot with tasty noodle soups and sandwiches. Prices are super reasonable and budget-friendly. I haven't tried their curries yet, but from the photos and ratings they've gotten here so far, I'm sure the curries are equally tasty.
author: Amy H.

description:
It's okay I guess.
They serve largeeee portions.
Personally I like currys less heavy and super spicy.
Not sure if I'd return... The food is okay.
author: Nona T.

description:
Chicken/pork katsu had a perfect crunch, the curry could be more flavorful though. Overall, decent price and good portion. Staff is very friendly and self-serve style which is perfect for the space and neighborhood. 

Will I come back again? Perhaps for lunch on a workday.
Quick tip: Order the volcano plate, it comes with soup and salad!
author: Johanna P.

description: Just had the day special, Spinach Chicken curry, was very tasty & hot spicy was not really very hot but adding one of their sauces made the meal even more satisfying... This is a good reasonable place for Japanese curry... Experience it!
author: Mo H.

description: I love coming here but tonight was bad! I called in a chicken curry order and the girl on the phone tells me 10 mins so I get there 15 mins later, I pay for my order and yet I still didn't get food yet. As I stand there while people after me get their food I get frustrated after an extra 10 mins of standing around I ask her "where's my food cuz I called it in?" She asks me what I order and I tell and she goes looking around ONLY FOR IT TO BE ON THE COUNTER BAGGED UP WAITING FOR ME!!! Absolutely annoying as fuck when my food is just sitting there waiting for me and you don't give it to me.
author: Easley W.

description: I've eaten here a few times since the first review and the curry had definitely improved! My favorite is the hamburger curry plate with a fried egg.
author: Anthony B.

description:
As I remember, the curry here is delicious, generous portions. Fresh rice, yummy katsu, warm and soft veggies. Topped with tasty red radish. The potato croquette topping is delicious here.

Self serve water and utensils, but they bring out the food to you. A neat combination of casual and service. Nice quiet place to go by yourself or with friends.
author: Corinne T.

description:
Straight up, one of my favorite restaurants in this city! Pretty much the best JapaCurry I've ever had in any city that I've been to. This place, being in the Richmond, seems to be as well known as Muracci's which is a shame. Muracci's doesn't even come close to Volcano. Their toppings are great and their curry is delicious. I can't even being to express how wonderful this place is. Not only is their service great (shout out to Tiffany) but if you came in just to have their food, then that alone deserves the 5 stars. I frequent this place probably once a week because it's that good. I'd probably go more but I don't live in the Richmond so it's not the most convenient to get to. 

When you come in, you order at the counter and then take a seat. The person behind the counter will then bring the food to you. So unlike a previous review saying that this is a "cafeteria style" place, it is not. I'm not sure what that person thinks is "cafeteria style".

Things I recommend: Tonkatsu Curry, Chicken Katsu Curry, Kara-age Chicken Curry, and pretty much any of their toppings.
author: Rylan C.

description: I would give them a five but from the last 2 recent visits, they've been really stingy with their curry sauce. It might be better to get it Togo to get more curry sauce in the container.
author: Diane D.

description:
My brother and his friends talked it up about this place to me for several years.  I didn't know what to expect when they decided to take me there a month or so ago.

They recommended me to try the curry chicken katsu with brown rice... let me tell you, brown rice complements curry so damned well. I had a yogurt flavored drink, sounds strange I know ...but it was all great. I recommend you guys try it, oh AND they have mochi ice cream and several levels of curry heat if you want a challenge
author: Lester A.

description:
I finally tried Japanese curry. It wasn't bad at all, but I still prefer Thai curry. That aside, Volcano serves up decent portions at a good price. I couldn't finish my plate! I asked for the medium level of spiciness, but it was way too spicy! Boyfriend got the mild, and it actually tastes much better (not as spicy, and had better curry flavor). I got the chicken katsu, and he got the pork katsu. Comes with a bunch of rice and a ton of curry sauce with a few chunks of veggies. You can add toppings if you want, but it seems kind of pricey to me. The plate is fine on its own!

This is a order and seat yourself type of place. The girl who took our order was nice, and answered all of our weird first-timer questions. If I ever crave Japanese curry, I'll definitely drop by.
author: Sara K.

description: I had chicken katsu curry tonight. It was crispy, juicy and not oily~ One of the best chicken cutlets I have ever had - including those I had in Japan.
author: Cindy C.

description:
The last time i came here was ages ago, since then Volcano has evolved and added more items to there menu and even got real plates instead of cafeteria style trays and paper plates. They have added a few different sandwiches and also added noodle soups.  I had the chance to try their chicken katsu sammich recently after drooling over a friends and watching my brother eat it too. 

http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/rujXqDhd9nW5Uak54d9p_Q/l

Nice and crunchy and tender in the center Chicken Katsu, topped with cabbage and tonkatsu sauce in btw two pieces of nice thick Japanese toast bread = Delicous!!!!  i will be back to try the other sandwiches and try the noodles soups and the curry once more!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Volcano is my go to spot for some mouth watering Japanese curry!!  I would always get their chicken katsu curry with a couple of sides for a couple dollars!  the restaurant is a order at the counter and wait for your food at your table kind of establishment. They give you the option to choose how spicy you want your curry to be, ranging from : Mild, Medium, Hot and Volcano ! 

This is my favorite place to grab some good eats with a budget and will be yours too if you give them a try !
author: Jeff C.

description:
Another one of my preferred to-go spot for a meal-on-the-go in my neighborhood. 

You can't go wrong with their curries. They also offer a good variety of add-ons including croquettes, calamari, veggies (zucchini, eggplant), and seasonal items that change from week to week. I like my chicken curry medium hot, and I can't say no to a croquette each time I go.

Right on the busy Geary Street close to Walgreens and Ross, so parking may be difficult. 

In the past year I've noticed them expanding their menu items to include noodles and other types of curries (like tomato beef). Kudos for continuously looking to diversify their menu to please more palates.

They offer a stamp card too to earn free curry toppings!
author: Jing D.

description:
Finally tried this local curry joint.  Right off the bat, I can give it 2 stars as its not very unique in flavor and can pass as a fast food joint.  Katsu and curry just in my mind doesn't have anything special, unless the curry sauce is out of this world and has a variety of spices.  

However, for $10 and opening till 9pm on a rainy Tuesday night, I could not care less what the taste was like (..initially).  But now that I'm full and have regained all sense of reality and taste between bitter and sweet, mushy and textured, I can say, it's mediocre.  

I had the Ton Katsu ($7.45) curry with Noodles (+$1.00) and then an extra side of zucchini veggies (+$1.50) all coming out to $10.00.  The noodles as claimed were of the thin udon type.  I'm not too sure of this, but I'll take their word on it since it wasn't mushy like spaghetti and it did have some sort of a bounce to it.  The curry....mild flavored, but has hints of curry taste and spice.  Other than that....it either makes me rethink my definition on curry or it leaves me wanting to call it something else that starts off sounding like "c-r....." (ap)

And for $1.50 just to add a side of veggies, mainly 4 pieces of zucchini chunks....that's about $0.32 cents a pop.  Do you know that you can get an entire zucchini for that much too?  

In any case, I even went home to fry an egg and a sausage to go with my meal since I saw egg on the menu but it was the boiled kind (eh) and the sausage addition for $1.50, though tempting, was not so tempting after someone on this page mentioned it looked like a breakfast sausage.  (no thanks.)

So was I happy with my meal or what?  Short answer....Yes.  It's a good takeout joint and quick fix to a curry craving.  Did it taste good and did I get everything I expected?  No.  I cried myself to sleep after that. 

But to give some credit, the price point is perhaps on point, and the lady taking my order was pretty nice about it.  

I'm looking at my loyalty card right....(chuckles)
author: Vincent K.

description: Nice little curry house in the neighborhood, I took my son to eat there a few times, and he loved it, we had the Chicken Katsu it was great, highly recommend it.
author: Terry T.

description: When I first walked in, it looked a little like a cafeteria style place, which kind of threw me off, but it was very clean, really fast, and super tasty curry.
author: Emmaline C.

description:
Since this is the only Japanese restaurant that specializes in Japanese curry in this part of town, I had to give it a try.  The menu is simple (which I like): sandwiches (Nobu K. recommends the chicken katsu sandwich), rice places (katsu, teriyaki), noodle soup, curry, toppings (e.g., sausage, cheese, boiled egg) and sides.  

* Chicken curry ($5.95).  You can specify hot or regular.  The delicious curry sauce was the highlight but everything else was just average (cheap ingredients).  The curry had a sweet, deep, complex flavor.  It was thin but not watery.  I think chili oil is added to make it spicy.  The curry came with big chunks of boneless chicken (all dark meat I think), huge chunks of carrot, potato and zucchini.  It was definitely homestyle.  They included a good amount of steamed white rice (brown rice is $1 extra).  

* Potato croquette ($1.25).  Crispy panko on the outside, creamy potato filling.  Good but average.  

They didn't have cake rolls or fro-yo but they did have a refrigerated case with drinks, imported Japanese crepes, Japanese pudding and Ciao Bella gelato.
author: Lolia S.

description:
My first experience with Japanese curry was when my upstairs neighbor's wife made some for us on Oscar night. 

My office manager suggested we get lunch here and boy, what a good idea that was. The curry was very tasty. Curry item comes with a good helping of rice.  I tried the katsu chicken as well as the fried shrimp one. Only spiff is that the curry doesn't come with more vegetables. I love the potatoes (so soft) and zuchinni. I just wished there was more of it! I'd take off another star because there was a long line to pick up our take out order when we called it in prior.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: The curry here is ok - it was a little on the sweet side for me. Perhaps it was from the katsu sauce?  But the portion sizes are huge. It's also very reasonable, but you do have to bus your own table.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I'm all about cheap fulfilling food and when my friend kept insisting that Volcano was beyond delicious, I decided that we go and have lunch there.

Now I'm a sucker for free food and when I stood in front of Volcano's cafe menu, pondering on the possibilities of which sides I should chose to envelope my main dish with, the counter lady straight laid a basket full of free fried bread covered in cinnamon. If I had no shame in being a cheap-skate, I def would have posted it by the counter and finish that basket of bread all to myself.

Well, I'm glad I really didn't partake in being a cheap-skate because the main entree was divine. Heavenly. Fulfilling. A freaking mess of a masterpiece that would have made any fat man wanna slap his mama. Okay, exaggeration. But with all honesty, my face lit up the second my plate was placed in front of me. Can you imagine veggies (potatoes, carrots, zucchinis), chicken, calamari, potato croquettes and rice all drenched in a rich, savory curry sauce. Forget imagining it, just look at this picture right there. Now that's whatimtaaaaalmbout.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WnQoN1uV65vacUj0q1TgoQ?select=DpEBr9hDoFafg4BspdSYig
author: Ally C.

description: A small and unassuming (but AWESOME) spot for curry over rice... And they have so many awesome add ons! Love this place :)
author: Lauren B.

description:
I would say this is one of the better places for japanese curry in the city and the best thing about it is that they're open on the weekends AND in the evenings! With the typical cool/cold weather in SF, you can pretty much enjoy a nice plate of curry any day! I think of it as one of my favorite comfort food :) 

When you enter, you go straight to the friendly cashier to order (menu is behind the cashier and hung by the restaurant window) and pay (credit card or cash). After you ordered, you can sit wherever is available (the place can fit about 20 people, which can be kind of small for their growing number of customer) and the food will be brought to you. Oh, I forgot to mention that you will have get your own water, silverware, and napkins. And when you're done, you can put your dirty dishes on the designated containers near the garbage by the door. (I like to think and hope it helps keep maintain their prices) Yes, I still give this place a 5-star even though I have to get and put away my dishes because their curry is delicious! 

I typically like to order either their original, which is a vegetarian dish with zucchinis, eggplants, carrots, potato, and of course, rice, or their katsu (chicken or pork) dish, which doesn't have as much veggies in there. They do have four levels of spiciness to choose from (mild, medium, hot, and volcano). For someone who can handle a good amount heat in their food, I would recommend the "hot", which is what I normally order. I order "volcano" level once in a long while since it does seem to over power their curry a bit. 

Compared to Muracci's, another popular Japanese curry place in the city, I think Volcano's curry is on the sweeter side-don't get me wrong, Muracci's is good too, but they only open M-F 11am-5 or 6pm. 

BONUS: this place offers their own little reward stamp card which gives a free topping for about every 3 dishes you order and by the 12th dish, you get a free curry AND a free topping!
author: Am Y.

description:
Large portions, quality curry, walking distance from Richmond, eat in or take out.

Would not mind coming back here to pick up food again as the go - to.

They offer a ton of add ons too for a little extra charge.
author: Thanh T.

description: I've lost count of the times I've came to Volcano. I really like the curry plates here. The girls at the cashier there were very sweet and served with a smile (how often do you experience friendliness in both cashier and service these days? None). Once you ordered from the counter, you seat yourself in one of the tables and wait for your order to arrive to you. Water is self-served. My favorite is their Chicken Katsu Curry plate with medium level spiciness. The chicken is always crispy and consistent. Curry was very flavorful. It went well with the rice, carrot, and potatoes. You will be full by the time you finish your plate. I've never tried the volcano level of spiciness but I heard it's a killer! Though I think the plates were slightly cheaper back then, but then again as long as the quality is consistent, I will keep coming whenever I crave for their curry.
author: Tony C.

description:
Fast Japanese food. Is anyone able to turn Japanese food, which is losing its yuppie cred, into a hip and somewhat trendy fast food joint? Well, I think volcano has an answer to that. 

Instead of lava, his place has a youthful vibe running along its mountainside. Volcano appeals to a younger audience, but that certainly does not mean everyone else is precluded. They seem to play "Now This Is What I Call Music" hits and sometimes Jack Johnson with no shame. They accept credit cards, for all the 20 somethings who don't have cash. Its cafeteria vibe evokes High School and dorm style cuisine. This is probably one of the few remaining places in SF where you can eat comfortably if you decided you didn't want to leave your pajamas that day. Also, their logo can best be described as cool because it isn't reminiscent of anything Japanese that I've ever seen. It seems to be inspired by tribal art, featuring a man and a woman cooking curry over a lava!

The food is quite good. I got a hot chicken karaage curry. The rice is authentic and what you would expect to get with Japanese curry, which is a good thing. It includes the pickled red vegetables, potatoes, and carrots. All was good besides the potatoes, which were strangely sour. The prices and spices are respectively reasonable and adequate. Also, make sure to get "volcano" if you can handle the highest heat at other restaurants. 

Though you pay up front for the food and clear your own plates. Sometimes, when the restaurant isn't too busy, the host will still bring you your food, and if you're really lucky, they'll even clear the plate for you! This is precisely what happened to me today. Surprising service for just a "cafeteria".
author: Alan H.

description: Dank curry. Volcano is spicy and a little sweet. The curry comes with carrots and potatoes. Great service. One of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Jack M.

description: This is a great casual place to eat at. Parking can be a little difficult at times. The portion sizes are decent and curry is flavorful. This is great on a rainy or cold day. I typically order the mild Katsu Curry with white rice. Do not forget to ask for extra pickles on your food. After eating here I like to walk next door to Joe's Ice Cream for dessert.
author: Marty M.

description:
*cheap delicious curry place that fills you up*
#homecooking
#awesomepainting

No really, that painting in there is phenomenal. A samurai...killing a snake...while holding a plate of katsu. That alone is worth going to this place. After a short hike, me and a friend were going to grab a burger next door but stumbled upon this place and very glad we did. 

All kinds of Japanese curry with a plentiful amount of fun sides to add that extra zing to your dish. This place is casual, tasty, filling, and above all feels like I ate a home cooked meal. The curry's hotness was 1-4, and the 3 was hot, and warranted a sniffle here and there. Perfect for what I was looking for. A hearty dish, simple menu, and quick service made this place a great experience.
author: Kevin T.

description: Just tried this place out yesterday and wasn't crazy about the curry. I had the Chicken Katsu Curry and total came out around $9. I have added a picture on here, and it was decent portion. It was prepared quickly and was presentable. There were some carrots and potatoes in the curry sauce. Honestly wasn't impressed and had better curry elsewhere. Just average.
author: Scott Y.

description:
Good for the price and what you get!  One of the cheapest meals you can get out of SF, and they are fast!

So far, I've tried: chicken curry, chicken katsu, fried shrimp, "musubi"...  It's good!  Great for times when you are in a hurry and don't feel like cooking!
author: Angelie A.

description:
I had the chicken curry here mild (I can't take spicy! haha) And I've had curry over in Japan and this is pretty authentic. Added some more fukujinzuke (even though some is already provided! I love that stuff). The chicken was tender and the curry was nice and warm. 

So basically if you're looking for good authentic curry, this is the place to go! :)
author: Tracy L.

description: I regularly visit this place. I like it. The Volcano spice level is actually spicy. I usually get the Karage here. Katsu is good too, but it can be dry here and there. Karage is usually on point. The pickles on top are a nice touch, although it would be nice to have it already on the table like I'm used to. (As much pickle as you want!)  It's a solid place to get curry if you're in a hurry, and the price is right where it should be.
author: Peter K.

description: I've tried Japanese curry from Tani's and , and by far,  this is my favorite spot. I'm a spicy girl so I settle for nothing less than the volcano level of spice, but apparently there is a secret menu where you can go hotter than volcano, but I'm trying to live past 30. Here's what you do. Call in your order 10 mins in advance, double park in front, run in, get your food, drive home as fast as you can, eat your curry, and pass out. There's nothing else you can do afterwards because it is thick, warm, and the ultimate comfort food. Get the chicken katsu curry. It is yummy, trust and believe.
author: Michelle R.

description:
The Richmond is an interesting place to find yourself in and definitely a place where you want to take advice from fellow Yelpers. 

For one, some streets are almost cafe strips, sushi, curry, Russian foods, cafes, coffee shops, Mexican, yet, you never really see any places with a line out the door. They all look a bit sketchy to me. 

Volcano was one of those places people at work kept talking about how good it was. Now, I have never been to Asia. I had never even heard about the concept of Japanese curry. It sounds kind of insane. Like an extreme hybrid between two cultures. So I gave Volcano a try. Not once, but twice. Once with a Scoutmob deal which they were not too happy to take. So I ask myself, why put your business on a deal if you don't want to honor it?

I'm going to say this one way, because it can only be said one way, the food is simply not that great. The portions are big, and the staff is nice, but that doesn't make up for the food. Add some flavor, please, because I think you are one of a kind in SF and you should make a difference for those who want to experience Japanese curry.
author: Alexia R.

description:
You know that feeling when you've had an utterly delicious dish in the past, and want to recreate that experience, and so venture forth and try the dish at a different place, only to have it fall the smallest bit flat? That's what happened to me here.

Don't make a mistake... this place is GOOD! Great, even, if you ask my partner (who simply inhaled his heaping plate of chicken katsu curry). But I'm still chasing the feeling of a perfect Japanese curry. This will work in a pinch, though. Lots of options (I really enjoyed my beef hamburger curry) and toppings (tip: the hardboiled egg is also deep fried). Fast service. Casual, order-at-the-register vibe. Affordable prices. My boyfriend can't wait to be back, and I won't mind coming along for the ride.
author: Julie D.

description:
There is one word I thought of after finishing my food: value.  For bang for your buck you can't go wrong with Volcano.  I decided to come here after hearing rave reviews from one of my good friends.  Being a big fan of fish, I ordered the fried white fish curry.  Once I sat order after quickly ordered my food, my dish arrived in a short 10 minutes to a heaping plate of rice, two large pieces of fish over curry w/ potatoes and carrots...all for $7.50.  The food was good- not great or out of this world, but it was good.  The other curry dishes around me looked very similar as it appeared the meats were not cooked in the curry, just served on top.

Like other reviews for Volcano, this simple yet quite satisfying establishment will bring me back here again.  Value my friends, value...
author: Natan O.

description:
Pretty good curry. I had chicken katsu curry and it was good. 
People say this place is cheap but thats only if you dont add anything in your curry. It only comes with the meat, and a few potatoes and carrots. 

very small cafe type place.
author: Erica L.

description:
+ Order at the counter and just find a seat. 
+ Colored cups for water on the side of the counter along with utensils.
- A pretty small space, about 6 tables.

Food:
+ Ordered the beef curry. ($7.50)
+ Food came out relatively fast.
+ Large portions.
- Large unappealing cuts of carrots and potatoes.
- Beef was slightly overcooked and dry.

Still a good place for a quick bite if you're in the area. I personally wouldn't go out of my way to eat here though.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Quick and reasonably priced "Japanese" Curry.  

"Why the quotes?" You ask?  Well, the curry here has the same flavor as Japanese curry, but it is WAY too runny.  There needs to be a thickness and this curry just doesn't have it.  A lot of people I know love it here, but I am looking for authentic so this place is not for me.  

Side note: I love the tsukemono (pickled vegetables...typically bright red or a beige color) that comes with Japanese curry, so I always ask for extra wherever I go.  They charge for that here...ughhhh.
author: Jessyca M.

description: Used to live nearby. I still go whenever possible. Love the curry, katsu sandwich, mini fish sandwich, and mini croquette sandwich... Seaweed salad also good.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Heard Volcano from a friend, and came here on a Sunday looking for some good hearty food to help recover from a hangover.  

I had the pork katsu curry and it was good, bordering on really good, but not excellent.  The katsu was very tasty and crispy.  The curry itself was flavorful, but personally I like my curry a little thicker.  

I think a big church group came in right before us, so Volcano's was packed.
